### Environment

* LWJGL version: 3.2.4-SNAPSHOT 
* LWJGL build #: 20190903.201424-1
* Java version: 12.0.2
* Platform: macOS 10.14.6
* Module: not sure

### Description

OpenGL windows on my Mac have screen tearing near the bottom of the screen, even with vsync on. It looks like this is a regression starting with 3.2.2. When I use version 3.2.1, the problem isn't there. Also, the problem isn't there on Windows with the latest LWJGL version.

[Example that shows the problem](https://gist.github.com/marshallsa/eaa57786ebccede81cde5ebd380022b6) based on the SimpleDrawElements demo from lwjgl3-demos.

When I run this example on 3.2.2 or newer, the screen tearing starts after a few seconds (before this, the animation is slow but doesn't tear). The screen tearing is only there when the window is near the bottom of the screen.

Using 3.2.1, the animation is always fast and smooth (no screen tearing).

body:
Same issue here with a Macbook pro running 10.14.6

My application (a simple grid scroller) is showing a lot of tearing around the bottom of the window. I cloned glfw and compiled at the _3.3_ tag to run the "Tests/tearing" application, and it shows extreme tearing too around the bottom.
The tearing actually gets wors as the swap_interval increases. Very surprisingly, there does not seem to be any tearing when the swap_interval is 0 (which should disable VSync, so it is strange). But as soon as the interval is set to 1 or more, the tearing becomes extremely noticeable.

Is there any progress on that front?

@elmindreda LWJGL users have been suffering from tearing since the move to CVDisplayLink and there's finally been a breakthrough that you may find interesting. Start [here](https://github.com/LWJGL/lwjgl3/issues/503#issuecomment-551304662) (19c0307dcbb1f345fce0f8d5251e81310a6f798f has been tested as well).

@Spasi Thank you for bringing hope back for macOS users! This tearing issue is very annoying at the moment, and would prevent any actual release on macOS targets.

Yet looking at the LWJGL thread you are linking to, as far as my limited understanding of the problem goes, it seems their conclusion is that building the JVM directly on their target platform solves all their issues. Is there some solution exportable to GLFW?

Yes what @Spasi said and additionally:

If you are currently running 10.14+ and the executable was built with or before 10.13 then it is likely you’ll see screen tearing with or without the swap interval workaround applied. In this case just building the executable with 10.14+ seems to fix the issue in both cases.

However, the original post had a problem with running on 10.12 which might not be related to the issue we discovered :/ (since what we found was especially a check for “was built on 10.14 or later otherwise do something else”)
Hopefully OpenGL swap interval is usable again now. If it is then 3.3.1 is ready for release.

issue.title: macOS: Use CVDisplayLink for vsync

repository.name: glfw
repository.description: A multi-platform library for OpenGL, OpenGL ES, Vulkan, window and input

issue.body:
Fixes #2249, #1834.

Somewhere along the line, Apple broke NSOpenGLCPSwapInterval. I've been researching this for the past week or so from various sources, and I decided to go ahead with using CVDisplayLink instead of NSOpenGLCPSwapInterval. SDL ended up doing the same thing (see issue thread [here](https://github.com/libsdl-org/SDL/issues/4918)).

I fixed it in my fork, and I decided to make this PR back to upstream for discussion on whether GLFW wants to go down this route as well.

The approach is very similar to SDL; pause the main thread right before swapping buffers in NSGL (in `glfwSwapBuffers`), and wait for the CVDisplayLink callback to continue. `glfwSwapInterval` is respected by waiting that many callbacks.

Because `cocoa_platform.h` uses a mutex, I had to shuffle around the includes in `internal.h` to get it included before `cocoa_platform.h`. I also had to add conditional variables to `posix_thread.h` and `win32_thread.h`. Multi-threading isn't my strong suite so I wouldn't be surprised if this can be improved further.
